oai_dc:dc.dc:title: When a science investigation is
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When a science investigation is done the way it was done before, we expect to get a very similar result. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:K, 1, 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: GEM:general science
McREL:scientific investigation
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: When a science investigation is
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When a science investigation is done again in a different place, we expect to get a very similar result. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:K, 1, 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:History and philosophy of science
GEM:general science
McREL:Scientific explanations
Scientific investigation
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sometimes similar investigations give different
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sometimes similar investigations give different results because of differences in the things being investigated, the methods used, or the circumstances in which the investigation is carried out, and sometimes just because of uncertainties in observations. It is not always easy to tell which. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:History and philosophy of science
GEM:general science
McREL:Scientific explanations
Scientific investigation
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scientific knowledge is subject to
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scientific knowledge is subject to modification as new information challenges prevailing theories and as a new theory leads to looking at old observations in a new way. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Current scientific knowledge and understanding guide scientific investigations. Different scientific domains employ different methods, core theories, and standards to advance scientific knowledge and understanding.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Formulate and revise scientific explanations and models using logic and evidence. Student inquiries should culminate in formulating an explanation or model. Models should be physical, conceptual, and mathematical. In the process of answering the questions, the students should engage in discussions and arguments that result in the revision of their explanations. These discussions should be based on scientific knowledge, the use of logic, and evidence from their investigation.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#hn,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard G History and Nature of Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Nature of science,Content Standard Text Level 3:Scientists formulate and test their explanations of nature using observation, experiments, and theoretical and mathematical models. Although all scientific ideas are tentative and subject to change and improvement in principle, for most major ideas in science, there is much experimental and observational confirmation. Those ideas are not likely to change greatly in the future. Scientists do and have changed their ideas about nature when they encounter new experimental evidence that does not match their existing explanations.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#hn,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard G History and Nature of Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Nature of scientific knowledge,Content Standard Text Level 3:Because all scientific ideas depend on experimental and observational confirmation, all scientific knowledge is, in principle, subject to change as new evidence becomes available. The core ideas of science such as the conservation of energy or the laws of motion have been subjected to a wide variety of confirmations and are therefore unlikely to change in the areas in which they have been tested. In areas where data or understanding are incomplete, such as the details of human evolution or questions surrounding global warming, new data may well lead to changes in current ideas or resolve current conflicts. In situations where information is still fragmentary, it is normal for scientific ideas to be incomplete, but this is also where the opportunity for making advances may be greatest.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:History and philosophy of science
GEM:general science
McREL:scientific explanations
scientific investigation
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Some scientific knowledge is very old and yet is still applicable today. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Some changes are so slow or so fast
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Some changes are so slow or so fast that they are hard to see. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:K, 1, 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Change is something that happens
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Change is something that happens to many things. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:K, 1, 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chunks of rocks come in
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chunks of rocks come in many sizes and shapes, from boulders to grains of sand and even smaller. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:K, 1, 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Soil consists of weathered rocks, decomposed organic material from dead plants, animals, and bacteria. Soils are often found in layers, with each having a different chemical composition and texture.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How fast things move differs greatly
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: How fast things move differs greatly. Some things are so slow that their journey takes a long time. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Things change in steady, repetitive
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Things change in steady, repetitive, or irregular ways-or sometimes in more than one way at the same time. Often the best way to tell which kinds of change are happening is to make a table or graph of measurments. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Waves, wind, water, and ice
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Waves, wind, water, and ice shape and reshape the earth's land surface by eroding rock and soil in some areas and depositing them in other areas, sometimes in seasonal layers. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Changes in earth and sky,Content Standard Text Level 3:The surface of the earth changes. Some changes are due to slow processes, such as erosion and weathering, and some changes are due to rapid processes such as landslides, volcanoes, and earthquakes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Things on or near the
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Things on or near the earth are pulled toward it by the earth's gravity. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Earth in the solar system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Gravity is the force that keeps planets in orbit around the sun and governs the rest of the motion in the solar system. Gravity alone holds us to the earth's surface and explains the phenomena of the tides.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rock is composed
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rock is composed of different combinations of minerals. Smaller rocks come from the breakage and weathering of bedrock and larger rocks. Soil is made partly from weathered rock, partly from plant remains-and also contains many living organisms. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Properties of earth materials,Content Standard Text Level 3:Soils have properties of color and texture, capacity to retain water, and ability to support the growth of many kinds of plants, including those in our food supply.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Soil consists of weathered rocks, decomposed organic material from dead plants, animals, and bacteria. Soils are often found in layers, with each having a different chemical composition and texture.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The interior of the earth is hot
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The interior of the earth is hot. Heat flow and movement of material within the earth cause earthquakes and volcanic eruptions and create mountains and ocean basins. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Natural hazards,Content Standard Text Level 3:Internal and external processes of the Earth system cause natural hazards, events that change or destroy human and wildlife habitats, damage property, and harm or kill humans. Natural hazards include earthquakes, landslides, wildfires, volcanic eruptions, floods, storms, and even possible impacts of asteroids.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:The solid Earth is layered with a lithosphere; hot, convecting mantle; and dense, metallic core.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Lithospheric plates on the scales of continents and oceans constantly move at rates of centimeters per year in response to movements in the mantle. Major geological events, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and mountain building, result from these plate motions.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Energy in the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:The outward transfer of earth's internal heat drives convection circulation in the mantle that propels the plates comprising earth's surface across the face of the globe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The earth first formed in
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The earth first formed in a molten state and then the surface cooled into solid rock. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vibrations in materials set up
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Vibrations in materials set up wavelike disturbances that spread away from the source. Sound and earthquake waves are examples. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#ps,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard B Physical Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Interactions of energy and matter,Content Standard Text Level 3:Waves, including sound and seismic waves, waves on water, and light waves, have energy and can transfer energy when they interact with matter.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Some changes in earth's surface...
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Some changes in the earth's surface are abrupt (such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions) while other changes happen very slowly (such as uplift and wearing down of mountains). This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Land forms are the result of a combination of constructive and destructive forces. Constructive forces include crustal deformation, volcanic eruption, and deposition of sediment, while destructive forces include weathering and erosion.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Science and technology in local challenges,Content Standard Text Level 3:Some environmental changes occur slowly, and others occur rapidly. Students should understand the different consequences of changing environments in small increments over long periods as compared with changing environments in large increments over short periods.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Changes in earth and sky,Content Standard Text Level 3:The surface of the earth changes. Some changes are due to slow processes, such as erosion and weathering, and some changes are due to rapid processes such as landslides, volcanoes, and earthquakes.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Origin and evolution of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Interactions among the solid earth, the oceans, the atmosphere, and organisms have resulted in the ongoing evolution of the earth system. We can observe some changes such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions on a human time scale, but many processes such as mountain building and plate movements take place over hundreds of millions of years.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The earth's surface is shaped
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The earth's surface is shaped in part by the motion of water and wind over very long times, which act to level mountain ranges. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Land forms are the result of a combination of constructive and destructive forces. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rivers and glacial ice
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rivers and glacial ice carry off soil and break down rock, eventually depositing the material in sediments or carrying it in solution to the sea. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sedimentary rock buried deep
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sedimentary rock buried deep enough may be reformed by pressure and heat, perhaps melting and recrystallizing into different kinds of rock. These re-formed rock layers may be forced up again to become land surface and even mountains. Subsequently, this new rock too will erode. Rock bears, evidence of the minerals, temperatures, and forces that created it. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Land forms are the result of a combination of constructive and destructive forces. Constructive forces include crustal deformation, volcanic eruption, and deposition of sediment, while destructive forces include weathering and erosion.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Some changes in the solid earth can be described as the "rock cycle." Old rocks at the earth's surface weather, forming sediments that are buried, then compacted, heated, and often recrystallized into new rock. Eventually, these new rocks may be brought to the surface by the forces that drive plate motions, and the rock cycle continues.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sediments of sand
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sediments of sand and smaller particles (sometimes containing the remains of organisms) are gradually buried and are cemented together by dissolved minerals to form solid rock again. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Some changes in the solid earth can be described as the "rock cycle." Old rocks at the earth's surface weather, forming sediments that are buried, then compacted, heated, and often recrystallized into new rock. Eventually, these new rocks may be brought to the surface by the forces that drive plate motions, and the rock cycle continues.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thousands of layers of sedimentary rock
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thousands of layers of sedimentary rock confirm the long history of the changing surface of the earth and the changing life forms whose remains are found in successive layers. The youngest layers are not always found on top, because of folding, breaking, and uplift of layers. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Earth's history,Content Standard Text Level 3:The Earth processes we see today, including erosion, movement of lithospheric plates, and changes in atmospheric composition, are similar to those that occurred in the past. Earth history is also influenced by occasional catastrophes, such as the impact of an asteroid or comet.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Earth's history,Content Standard Text Level 3:Fossils provide important evidence of how life and environmental conditions have changed.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Origin and evolution of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Geologic time can be estimated by observing rock sequences and using fossils to correlate the sequences at various locations. Curent methods include using the known decay rates of radioactive isotopes present in rocks to measure the time since the rock was formed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: There are a variety of different
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: There are a variety of different land forms on the earth's surface (such as coastlines, rivers, mountains, deltas, and canyons). This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Earthquakes often occur along the boundaries
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Earthquakes often occur along the boundaries between colliding plates, and molten rock from below creates pressure that is released by volcanic eruptions, helping to build up mountains. Under the ocean basins, molten rock may well up between separating plates to create new ocean floor. Volcanic activity along the ocean floor may form undersea mountains, which can thrust above the ocean's surface to become islands. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Lithospheric plates on the scales of continents and oceans constantly move at rates of centimeters per year in response to movements in the mantle. Major geological events, such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and mountain building, result from these plate motions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scientific evidence implies that some
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Scientific evidence implies that some rock near the earth's surface is several billion years old. But until the 19th century, most people believed that the earth was created just a few thousand years ago. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The formation, weathering, sedimentation, and reformation of rock
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The formation, weathering, sedimentation, and reformation of rock constitute a continuing "rock cycle" in which the total amount of material stays the same as its forms change. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Some changes in the solid earth can be described as the "rock cycle." Old rocks at the earth's surface weather, forming sediments that are buried, then compacted, heated, and often recrystallized into new rock. Eventually, these new rocks may be brought to the surface by the forces that drive plate motions, and the rock cycle continues.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Matching coastlines and similarities
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Computers have become invaluable in
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Computers have become invaluable in science, mathematics, and technology because they speed up and extend people's ability to collect, store, compile, and analyze data; prepare research reports; and share data and ideas with investigators all over the world. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Use appropriate tools and techniques to gather, analyze, and interpret data. The use of tools and techniques, including mathematics, will be guided by the question asked and the investigations students design. The use of computers for the collection, summary, and display of evidence is part of this standard. Students should be able to access, gather, store, retrieve, and organize data, using hardware and software designed for these uses.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Use technology and mathematics to improve investigations and communications. A variety of technologies, such as hand tools, measuring instruments, and calculators, should be an integral component of scientific investigations. The use of computers for the collection, analysis, and display of data is also a part of this standard. Mathematics plays an essential role in all aspects of an inquiry. For example, measurement is used for posing questions, formulas are used for developing explanations, and charts and graphs are used for communicating results.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Accurate record-keeping, openness, and
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Accurate record-keeping, openness, and replication are essential for maintaining an investigator's credibility with other scientists and society. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade: 5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry Standards,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Science advances through legitimate skepticism. Asking questions and querying other scientists' explanations is part of scientific inquiry. Scientists evaluate the explanations proposed by other scientists by examining evidence, comparing evidence, identifying faulty reasoning, pointing out statements that go beyond the evidence, and suggesting alternative explanations for the same observations.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade: 5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#hn,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard G History and Nature of Science Standards,Content Standard Text Level 2:Nature of science,Content Standard Text Level 3:It is part of scientific inquiry to evaluate the results of scientific investigations, experiments, observations, theoretical models, and the explanations proposed by other scientists. Evaluation includes reviewing the experimental procedures, examining the evidence, identifying faulty reasoning, pointing out statements that go beyond the evidence, and suggesting alternative explanations for the same observations. Although scientists may disagree about explanations of phenomena, about interpretations of data, or about the value of rival theories, they do agree that questioning, response to criticism, and open communication are integral to the process of science. As scientific knowledge evolves, major disagreements are eventually resolved through such interactions between scientists.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade: 9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry Standards,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Communicate and defend a scientific argument.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry Standards,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Scientific explanations must adhere to criteria such as, a proposed explanation must be logically consistent; it must abide by the rules of evidence; it must be open to questions and possible modification; and it must be based on historical and current scientific knowledge.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade: 9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry Standards,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Results of scientific inquiry--new knowledge and methods--emerge from different types of investigations and public communication among scientists. In communicating and defending the results of scientific inquiry, arguments must be logical and demonstrate connections between natural phenomena, investigations, and the historical body of scientific knowledge. In addition, the methods and procedures that scientists used to obtain evidence must be clearly reported to enhance opportunities for further investigation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Science disciplines differ from one
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Science disciplines differ from one another in what is studied, techniques used, and outcomes sought, but they share a common purpose and philosophy, and all are part of the same scientific enterprise. Although each discipline provides a conceptual structure for organizing and pursuing knowledge, many problems are studied by scientists using information and skills from many disciplines. Disciplines do not have fixed boundaries, and it happens that new scientific disciplines are being formed where existing ones meet and that some subdisciplines spin off to become new disciplines in their own right. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about science and technology,Content Standard Text Level 3:Scientists in different disciplines ask different questions, use different methods of investigation, and accept different types of evidence to support their explanations. Many scientific investigations require the contributions of individuals from different disciplines, including engineering. New disciplines of science, such as geophysics and biochemistry often emerge at the interface of two older disciplines.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The strongly held traditions of
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The strongly held traditions of science, including its commitment to peer review and publication, serve to keep the vast majority of scientists well within the bounds of ethical professional behavior. Deliberate deceit is rare and likely to be exposed sooner or later by the scientific enterprise itself. When violations of these scientific ethical traditions are discovered, they are strongly condemned by the scientific community, and the violators then have difficulty regaining the respect of other scientists. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#hn,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard G History and Nature of Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Science as a human endeavor,Content Standard Text Level 3:Scientists have ethical traditions. Scientists value peer review, truthful reporting about the methods and outcomes of investigations, and making public the results of work. Violations of such norms do occur, but scientists responsible for such violations are censured by their peers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mathematical ideas can be represented concretely, graphically, and symbolically. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Usually there is no one
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Usually there is no one right way to solve a mathematical problem; different methods have different advantages and disadvantages. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Logical connections can be found
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Logical connections can be found between different parts of mathematics. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mathematics is the study of
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mathematics is the study of any patterns or relationships, whereas natural science is concerned only with those patterns that are relevant to the observable world. Although mathematics began long ago in practical problems, it soon focused on abstractions from the material world, and then on even more abstract relationships among those abstractions. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: As in other sciences, simplicity
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: As in other sciences, simplicity is one of the highest values in mathematics. Some mathematicians try to identify the smallest set of rules from which many other propositions can be logically derived. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Theories and applications in mathematical
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Theories and applications in mathematical work influence each other. Sometimes a practical problem leads to the development of new mathematical theories; often mathematics developed for its own sake turns out to have practical applications. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mathematics is helpful in almost every kind of human endeavor -- from laying bricks to prescribing medicine or drawing a face. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mathematics and science as enterprises share many values and features: belief in order, ideals of honesty and openness, the importance of criticism by colleagues, and the essential role played by imagination. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mathematics provides a precise language to describe objects and events and the relationships among them. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: In using mathematics, choices have
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In using mathematics, choices have to be made about what operations will give the best results. Results should always be judged by whether they make sense and are useful. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mathematicians often represent things with
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mathematicians often represent things with abstract ideas, such as numbers or perfectly straight lines, and then work with those ideas alone. The "things" from which they abstract can be ideas themselves. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Much of the work of
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Much of the work of mathematicians involves a modeling cycle, consisting of three steps: (1) using abstractions to represent things or ideas, (2) manipulating the abstractions according to some logical rules, and (3) checking how well the results match the original things or ideas. The actual thinking need not follow this order. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:mathematics
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tools are used to do
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tools are used to do things better or more easily and to do some things that could not otherwise be done at all. In technology, tools are used to observe, measure, and make things. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:K, 1, 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Employ simple equipment and tools to gather data and extend the senses. In early years, students develop simple skills, such as how to observe, measure, cut, connect, switch, turn on and off, pour, hold, tie, and hook. Beginning with simple instruments, students can use rulers to measure the length, height, and depth of objects and materials; thermometers to measure temperature; watches to measure time; beam balances and spring scales to measure weight and force; magnifiers to observe objects and organisms; and microscopes to observe the finer details of plants, animals, rocks, and other materials. Children also develop skills in the use of computers and calculators for conducting investigations.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about science and technology,Content Standard Text Level 3:Tools help scientists make better observations, measurements, and equipment for investigations. They help scientists see, measure, and do things that they could not otherwise see, measure, and do.

GEM:technology

technology

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Technology enables scientists and others to observe things that are too small or too far away to be seen otherwise and to study the motion of objects that are moving very rapidly or are hardly moving at all. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Measuring instruments can be used to gather accurate information for making scientific comparisons of objects and events and for designing and constructing things that will work properly. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Technology extends the ability of
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Technology extends the ability of people to change the world: to cut, shape, or put together materials; to move things from one place to another; and to reach farther with their hands, voices, senses, and minds. The changes may be for survival needs such as food, shelter, and defense; for communication and transportation; or to gain knowledge and express ideas. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities of technological design,Content Standard Text Level 3:Identify appropriate problems for technological design. Students should develop their abilities by identifying a specified need, considering its various aspects, and talking to different potential users or beneficiaries. They should appreciate that for some needs, the cultural backgrounds and beliefs of different groups can affect the criteria for a suitable product.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities of technological design,Content Standard Text Level 3:Implement a proposed solution. A variety of skills can be needed in proposing a solution depending on the type of technology that is involved. The construction of artifacts can require the skills of cutting, shaping, treating, and joining common materials--such as wood, metal, plastics, and textiles. Solutions can be implemented using computer software.

oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In earlier times, the accumulated information and techniques of each generation of workers were taught on the job directly to the next generation of workers. Today, the knowledge base for technology can be found as well in libraries of print and electronic resources and is often taught in the classroom. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Technology is essential to science
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Technology is essential to science for such purposes as access to outer space and other remote locations, sample collection and treatment, measurement, data collection and storage, computation, and communication of information. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Use appropriate tools and techniques to gather, analyze, and interpret data. The use of tools and techniques, including mathematics, will be guided by the question asked and the investigations students design. The use of computers for the collection, summary, and display of evidence is part of this standard. Students should be able to access, gather, store, retrieve, and organize data, using hardware and software designed for these uses.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Technology used to gather data enhances accuracy and allows scientists to manipulate and quantify results of investigations.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about science and technology,Content Standard Text Level 3:Science and technology are reciprocal. Science helps drive technology, as it addresses questions that demand more sophisticated instruments and provides principles for better instrumentation and technique. Technology is essential to science, because it provides instruments and techiques that enable observations of objects and phenomena that are otherwise unobservable due to factors, such as quantity, distance, location, size, and speed. Technology also provides tools for investigations, inquiry, and analysis.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Use technology and mathematics to improve investigations and communications. A variety of technologies, such as hand tools, measuring instruments, and calculators, should be an integral component of scientific investigations. The use of computers for the collection, analysis, and display of data is also a part of this standard. Mathematics plays an essential role in all aspects of an inquiry. For example, measurement is used for posing questions, formulas are used for developing explanations, and charts and graphs are used for communicating results.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Scientists rely on technology to enhance the gathering and manipulation of data. New techniques and tools provide new evidence to guide inquiry and new methods to gather data, thereby contributing to the advance of science. The accuracy and precision of the data, and therefore the quality of the exploration, depends on the technology used.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Technological problems and advances often create a demand for new scientific knowledge, and new technologies make it possible for scientists to extend their research in new ways or to undertake entirely new lines of research. The very availability of new technology itself often sparks scientific advances. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#si,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard A Science as Inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about scientific inquiry,Content Standard Text Level 3:Scientific investigations sometimes result in new ideas and phenomena for study, generate new methods or procedures for an investigation, or develop new technologies to improve the collection of data. oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mathematics, creativity, logic and originality are all needed to improve technology. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Technology usually affects society more
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Technology usually affects society more directly than science because it solves practical problems and serves human needs (and may create new problems and needs). In contrast, science affects society mainly by stimulating and satisfying people's curiosity and occasionally by enlarging or challenging their views of what the world is like. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about science and technology,Content Standard Text Level 3:Scientific inquiry and technological design have similarities and differences. Scientists propose explanations for questions about the natural world, and engineers propose solutions relating to human problems, needs, and aspirations. Technological solutions are temporary; technologies exist within nature and so they cannot contravene physical or biological principles; technological solutions have side effects; and technologies cost, carry risks, and provide benefits.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:technology
GEM:technology
McREL:science
technology
and society
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: People may not be able
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: People may not be able to actually make or do everything that they can design. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:K, 1, 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities of technological design,Content Standard Text Level 3:Propose a solution. Students should make proposals to build something or get something to work better; they should be able to describe and communicate their ideas. Students should recognize that designing a solution might have constraints, such as cost, materials, time, space, or safety.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: There is no perfect design
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: There is no perfect design. Designs that are best in one respect (safety or ease of use, for example) may be inferior in other ways (cost or appearance). Usually some features must be sacrificed to get others. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about science and technology,Content Standard Text Level 3:Perfectly designed solutions do not exist. All technological solutions have trade-offs, such as safety, cost, efficiency, and appearance. Engineers often build in back-up systems to provide safety. Risk is part of living in a highly technological world. Reducing risk often results in new technology.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities of technological design,Content Standard Text Level 3:Evaluate the solution and its consequences. Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities of technological design,Content Standard Text Level 3:Propose a solution. Students should make proposals to build something or get something to work better; they should be able to describe and communicate their ideas. Students should recognize that designing a solution might have constraints, such as cost, materials, time, space, or safety.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:K-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Abilities of technological design,Content Standard Text Level 3:Evaluate a product or design. Students should evaluate their own results or solutions to problems, as well as those of other children, by considering how well a product or design met the challenge to solve a problem. When possible, students should use measurements and include constraints and other criteria in their evaluations. Students should modify designs based on the results of evaluations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Transportation, communications, nutrition, sanitation, health care, entertainment, and other technologies give large numbers of people today the goods and services that once were luxuries enjoyed only by the wealthy. oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Technology is largely responsible for the great revolutions in agriculture, manufacturing, sanitation and medicine, warfare, transportation, information processing, and communications that have radically changed how people live and work. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Science and technology in society,Content Standard Text Level 3:Science influences society through its knowledge and world view. Scientific knowledge and the procedures used by scientists influence the way many individuals in society think about themselves, others, and the environment. The effect of science on society is neither entirely beneficial nor entirely detrimental. Societal challenges often inspire questions for scientific research, and social priorities often influence research priorities through the availability of funding for research.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rarely are technology issues simple
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Rarely are technology issues simple and one-sided. Relevant facts alone, even when known and available, usually do not settle matters. That is because contending groups may have different values and priorities. They may stand to gain or lose in different degrees, or may make very different predictions about what the future consequences of the proposed action will be. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Societies influence what aspects of
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Societies influence what aspects of technology are developed and how these are used. People control technology (as well as science) and are responsible for its effects. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Science and technology in society,Content Standard Text Level 3:Technology influences society through its products and processes. Technological changes are often accompanied by social, political, and economic changes that can be beneficial or detrimental to individuals and to society. Social needs, attitudes, and values influence the direction of technological development.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Social and economic forces strongly
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Social and economic forces strongly influence which technologies will be developed and used. Which will prevail is affected by many factors, such as personal values, consumer acceptance, patent laws, the availability of risk capital, the federal budget, local and national regulations, media attention, economic competition, and tax incentives. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12

Funding priorities for specific health problems serve as examples of ways that social issues influence science and technology.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Some scientists and engineers are
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Some scientists and engineers are comfortable working in situations in which some secrecy is required, but others prefer not to do so. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The human species has a
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The human species has a major impact on other species in many ways: reducing the amount of the earth's surface available to those other species, interfering with their food sources, changing the temperature and chemical composition of their habitats, introducing foreign species into their ecosystems, and altering organisms directly through selective breeding and genetic engineering. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#ls,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard C Life Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:The interdependence of organisms,Content Standard Text Level 3:Human beings live within the world's ecosystems. Increasingly, humans modify ecosystems as a result of population growth, technology, and consumption. Human destruction of habitats through direct harvesting, pollution, atmospheric changes, and other factors is threatening current global stability, and if not addressed, ecosystems will be irreversibly affected.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Science and technology in local, national, and global challenges,Content Standard Text Level 3:Humans have a major effect on other species. For example, the influence of humans on other organisms occurs through land use -- which decreases space available to other species--and pollution -- which changes the chemical composition of air, soil, and water.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: DLESE:human geography
environmental science
GEM:earth science
McREL:relationships between organisms and the environment
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Human inventiveness has brought new
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Human inventiveness has brought new risks as well as improvements to human existence. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Natural and human-induced hazards,Content Standard Text Level 3:Natural and human-induced hazards present the need for humans to assess potential danger and risk. Many changes in the environment designed by humans bring benefits to society, as well as cause risks. Students should understand the costs and trade-offs of various hazards--ranging from those with minor risk to a few people to major catastrophes with major risk to many people. The scale of events and the accuracy with which scientists and engineers can (and cannot) predict events are important considerations.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Environmental quality,Content Standard Text Level 3:Natural ecosystems provide an array of basic processes that affect humans. Those processes include maintenance of the quality of the atmosphere, generation of soils, control of the hydrologic cycle, disposal of wastes, and recycling of nutrients. Humans are changing many of these basic processes, and the changes may be detrimental to humans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Many chunks of rock orbit
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Many chunks of rock orbit the sun. Those that meet the earth glow and disintegrate from friction as they plunge through the atmosphere -- and sometimes impact the ground. Other chunks of rock mixed with ice have long, off-center orbits that carry them close to the sun, where the sun's radiation (of light and particles) boils off frozen materials from their surfaces and pushes it into a long, illuminated tail. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Increasingly sophisticated technology is used
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Increasingly sophisticated technology is used to learn about the universe. Visual, radio, and x-ray telescopes collect information from across the entire spectrum of electromagnetic waves; computers handle an avalanche of data and increasingly complicated computations to interpret them; space probes send back data and materials from the remote parts of the solar system; and accelerators give subatomic particles energies that simulate conditions in the stars and in the early history of the universe before stars formed. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:9, 10, 11, 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#st,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard E Science and Technology,Content Standard Text Level 2:Understandings about science and technology,Content Standard Text Level 3:Science and technology are reciprocal. Science helps drive technology, as it addresses questions that demand more sophisticated instruments and provides principles for better instrumentation and technique. Technology is essential to science, because it provides instruments and techiques that enable observations of objects and phenomena that are otherwise unobservable due to factors, such as quantity, distance, location, size, and speed. Technology also provides tools for investigations, inquiry, and analysis.

Although all scientific ideas are tentative and subject to change and improvement in principle, for most major ideas in science, there is much experimental and observational confirmation. Those ideas are not likely to change greatly in the future. Scientists do and have changed their ideas about nature when they encounter new experimental evidence that does not match their existing explanations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: When liquid water disappears, it turns into a gas (vapor) in the air and can reappear as a liquid when cooled, or as a solid if cooled below the freezing point of water. Clouds and fog are made of tiny droplets or frozen crystals of water. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Water, which covers the majority of the earth's surface, circulates through the crust, oceans, and atmosphere in what is known as the "water cycle." Water evaporates from the earth's surface, rises and cools as it moves to higher elevations, condenses as rain or snow, and falls to the surface where it collects in lakes, oceans, soil, and in rocks underground.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Clouds, formed by the condensation of water vapor, affect weather and climate.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Air is a material that
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Air is a material that surrounds us and takes up space and whose movement we feel as wind. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:3, 4, 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Atmospheric science
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The earth is mostly rock
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The earth is mostly rock. Three-fourths of its surface is covered by a relatively thin layer of water (some of it frozen), and the entire planet is surrounded by a relatively thin blanket of air. It is the only body in the solar system that appears able to support life. The and conditions very different from the earth's. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Water, which covers the majority of the earth's surface, circulates through the crust, oceans, and atmosphere in what is known as the "water cycle." Water evaporates from the earth's surface, rises and cools as it moves to higher elevations, condenses as rain or snow, and falls to the surface where it collects in lakes, oceans, soil, and in rocks underground.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:The atmosphere is a mixture of nitrogen, oxygen, and trace gases that include water vapor. The atmosphere has different properties at different elevations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Everything on or anywhere near the earth
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Everything on or anywhere near the earth is pulled toward the earth's center by gravitational force. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade: 5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science Standards,Content Standard Text Level 2:Earth in the solar system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Gravity is the force that keeps planets in orbit around the sun and governs the rest of the motion in the solar system. Gravity alone holds us to the earth's surface and explains the phenomena of the tides.
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Because the earth turns daily
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Because the earth turns daily on an axis that is tilted relative to the plane of the earth's yearly orbit around the sun, sunlight falls more intensely on different parts of the earth during the year. The difference in heating of the earth's surface produces the planet's seasons and weather patterns. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Earth in the solar system,Content Standard Text Level 3:The sun is the major source of energy for phenomena on the earth's surface, such as growth of plants, winds, ocean currents, and the water cycle. Seasons result from variations in the amount of the sun's energy hitting the surface, due to the tilt of the earth's rotation on its axis and the length of the day.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Atmospheric science
Climatology
Space science
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The moon's orbit around the earth
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The moon's orbit around the earth once in about 28 days changes what part of the moon is lighted by the sun and how much of that part can be seen from the earth--the phases of the moon. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade: 5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science Standards,Content Standard Text Level 2:Earth in the solar system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Most objects in the solar system are in regular and predictable motion. Those motions explain such phenomena as the day, the year, phases of the moon, and eclipses.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Space sciences
Motion of the Earth and Moon
Space science
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: Copyright 2004 by American Association for the Advancement of Science

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Climates have sometimes changed abruptly
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Climates have sometimes changed abruptly in the past as a result of volcanic eruptions or impacts of huge rocks from space. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:k-4,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6c.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Changes in environments,Content Standard Text Level 3:Some environmental changes occur slowly, and others occur rapidly. Students should understand the different consequences of changing environments in small increments over long periods as compared with changing environments in large increments over short periods.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#sp,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard F Science in Personal and Social Perspectives,Content Standard Text Level 2:Natural hazards,Content Standard Text Level 3:Internal and external processes of the Earth system cause natural hazards, events that change or destroy human and wildlife habitats, damage property, and harm or kill humans. Natural hazards include earthquakes, landslides, wildfires, volcanic eruptions, floods, storms, and even possible impacts of asteroids.

Standard Name:NSES,Grade:9-12,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6e.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Origin and evolution of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Interactions among the solid earth, the oceans, the atmosphere, and organisms have resulted in the ongoing evolution of the earth system. We can observe some changes such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions on a human time scale, but many processes such as mountain building and plate movements take place over hundreds of millions of years.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Water evaporates from the surface
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Stedman Willard
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Science
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Water evaporates from the surface of the earth, rises and cools, condenses into rain or snow, and falls again to the surface. The water falling on land collects in rivers and lakes, soil, and porous layers of rock, and much of it flows back into the oceans. The cycling of water in and out of the atmosphere is a significant aspect of the weather patterns on Earth. This benchmark addresses following educational levels:6, 7, 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:conformsTo: Standard Name:NSES,Grade:5-8,Identifier:http://books.nap.edu/html/nses/6d.html#es,Content Standard Text Level 1:Content Standard D Earth and Space Science,Content Standard Text Level 2:Structure of the earth system,Content Standard Text Level 3:Water, which covers the majority of the earth's surface, circulates through the crust, oceans, and atmosphere in what is known as the "water cycle." Water evaporates from the earth's surface, rises and cools as it moves to higher elevations, condenses as rain or snow, and falls to the surface where it collects in lakes, oceans, soil, and in rocks underground.
